The principles and meanings are truly correct, matching the subtle purport of the sutras.
However, he established his life on compassion and forgiveness, and perfected his nature with respect and harmony.
His mind is not outside the Way, and his practice is in front of the teachings.
The ground of precepts is level and still.
The water of concentration is deep and pure.
He thoroughly understands the origin of the characters in the sutras and explores the meaning of the sounds in the treatises.
His appearance and demeanor are auspicious and correct, and his diligence and integrity are lofty and intense.
The sound of his recitation continues from dusk to dawn.
His Dharma words encompass the inner and outer teachings.
He likes to stay in a proper place and simplify his work.
He values few desires and resting from seeking.
He is never tired of teaching others and goes beyond benefiting himself.

Åšramaá¹‡a Xuanzang.
He was a person from Luoyang, Henan.
His secular surname was Chen.

He was a descendant of Chen Zhonggong of Yecheng.ğŸ”½At the age of learning to ride a cart, he entered the monastic order.ğŸ”½By the time he could ride a bamboo horse, he had penetrated the mysteries.
His appearance was as lofty as a sword-edge piercing the sky, and his spiritual energy was as bright as the moon.
The famous virtuous monks in the capital all accepted him.
However, as the years passed, the four suburbs became filled with great virtuous and eminent monks, just like the Dharma masters of Xishu.
In the years of aspiring to study, he went to seek the Way and stayed there.
Before long, he thoroughly understood the half and full [teachings].
The disciples of the two rivers were all amazed and delighted.
After completing the precepts, he specialized in the Vinaya.
His demeanor was auspicious and his conduct was a model for the masses.
When Emperor Wu established the capital,
the literary norms were the same everywhere, and he followed friends to the Jiang River.
On the way, he passed through Yan and Ying.
At that time, King Han Yang was entrusted with the governorship of Jing and Chu.
Having heard of his high reputation before, he earnestly requested him to expound [the Dharma].
Then, at Tianhuang Temple in Jingzhou,
he lectured on the MahÄyÄna-samgraha and Abhidharma treatises.
Famous monks from the Huai and Hai regions admired him from afar and gathered like clouds.
The king and his officials personally visited the Dharma assembly.
The Dharma master analyzed the subtle and penetrated the essence, marveling at the principle.
The king and officials of great knowledge attained what they had never had before.
At that time, the great virtuous Dharma masters Zhiyan and others,
were all the spiritual leaders of the Jiang and Han regions, with a thorough understanding of the Tripiá¹­aka.
Having seen the Dharma master's marvelous and unobstructed eloquence,
they wept and sighed, saying,
How could we have expected that the soft elm tree would not shine, yet get to encounter the initial radiance of the great sun?
Thus, in the year of indulging the mind, the Dharma master finally paid homage to Master Xuanzang.
From then on, he studied the clues and tracks,
and explored the profound meanings in the eight repositories.
He always lamented that the teachings were incomplete and the translators were obscured, causing the precious wish-fulfilling jewel to be incomplete,
and the verses of the Snow Mountain to be still half.
Thereupon, he carried his staff and wrapped his feet, traversing dangers as if they were level ground.
Having reached the land of India, he consulted without weariness.
The scriptures of the five sciences and four Agamas,
the clues of the three repositories and twelve branches,
The seven examples and eight transformations of sound,
The three sounds and six explanations of the sentences,
All exhaust their subtlety and thoroughly investigate their wonderfulness.
However, those of the Lesser Vehicle and even the non-Buddhists,
Each concocted different theories and slandered the Great Vehicle.
The Dharma Master then composed the Treatise on Constraining Evil Views.
Constraining the Lesser Vehicle of the eighteen schools,
Destroying the ninety-five kinds of non-Buddhist paths,
And also composing the Treatise on Reconciliation,
Blending the subtle meanings of the Yoga and Middle Treatise,
In order to calm the confusion of the Great Vehicle.
At that time, King Ká¹›kin of Central India was the overlord of the five Indian countries.
He was well-versed in both Buddhist and non-Buddhist teachings and was exceptionally talented.
He read this treatise and said in admiration,
Although it has the distinction of revealing the great and destroying the false,
It shows contempt for the people of our great summer.
I am about to hold a great offering for ninety days.
We can use this assembly to determine what is right and wrong.
He then sent messengers to spread the word to all ten thousand li.
All the debaters belonging to the various countries that had come were gathered.
The great assembly gathered together.
The Dharma Master wrote the two treatises he had composed, totaling over six thousand verses,
and wrote them on the gate of the Great Offering Ground, saying:
If anyone can refute even one verse, I will cut off my tongue and apologize.
Day after day, he beat the drum, challenging debaters.
For eighteen days,
no one dared to accept the challenge.
At that time, King Ká¹›kin and others, the great and small vehicle masters of Buddhism and non-Buddhist paths,
were all amazed and embarrassed. The Dharma Master had studied and discussed,
traveling through more than a hundred countries for seventeen years.
In the nineteenth year of the Zhenguan era, he returned to China.
He met the Emperor in Luoyang, the capital.
The Emperor was greatly delighted and immediately ordered the six hundred and fifty-seven Sanskrit texts he had brought
to be translated at Hongfu Temple in the Western Capital.
He also ordered the Left Premier, Fang Xuanling,
to widely summon more than fifty eminent monks, including Huiming and Lingrun, to assist in spreading the Dharma.
And ordered the Crown Prince's Left Attendant Gentleman Xu Jingzong and others to be in charge of the translation.
In the twenty-second year, the translated sutras were presented to the emperor.
At that time, Emperor Taizong of the Great Tang Dynasty.
With the intention of enlightenment, he composed a preface to the profound examination.
The brilliant celestial phenomena shine like the sun and moon, and the splendor is exalted.
The emperor, with literary thoughts and admiration, expounds the wise thoughts and composes the record.
The sacred writings shine and adorn, like clouds and mist spreading colorful patterns.
Moreover, in the twelfth month of that year, the emperor was in the Eastern Palace.
He was alert to the consideration of great filial piety and moved by the thought of holy goodness.
He respectfully created the Great Compassionate Kindness Temple.ğŸ”½And the Sutra Translation Court for the Empress Dowager Wen De.

At that time, the two palaces in the east and west greatly produced banners and images.
The emperor ordered the nine musical bureaus and the precious banners, canopies, colorful flowers, and wonderful incense of the various temples in the capital.
And the precious carriages and various skills of the Wannian and Chang'an wards.

Resided in the Ci'en Temple and the translation temple.
